message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The corneal deposits suggest the patient has been taking Chlorpromazine. Clozapine, Thioridazine, and Ziprasidone do not commonly cause corneal deposits.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of corneal deposits suggests the patient has been taking Chlorpromazine, which is known to cause ocular side effects including deposits in the cornea. None of the other options are associated with this specific side effect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The discrete brown deposits on the corneal epithelium in both eyes suggest the presence of corneal verticillata, which is often seen in patients taking chlorpromazine. None of the other listed antipsychotic drugs are associated with this side effect.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Brown deposits on the corneal epithelium is a characteristic side effect of chlorpromazine. None of the other options have this side effect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The brown deposits on the corneal epithelium are a side effect of long-term use of chlorpromazine, which is an older first-generation antipsychotic drug. Clozapine, thioridazine, and ziprasidone are all second-generation antipsychotic drugs and do not typically cause this side effect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The brown deposits on the corneal epithelium are known as Kayser-Fleischer rings and are characteristic of Wilson's disease. Among the options, only Chlorpromazine has been associated with inducing Wilson's disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The brown deposits on the corneal epithelium are known as Kayser-Fleischer rings, which are a sign of Wilson's disease. Among the antipsychotic drugs listed, only Chlorpromazine is known to cause copper metabolism disorders like Wilson's disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The brown deposits on the corneal epithelium suggest the use of chlorpromazine, which is known for causing corneal deposits as a side effect. None of the other options are associated with this specific side effect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The corneal deposits are likely to be Vortex Keratopathy, which is most commonly associated with chlorpromazine use. None of the other options are known to cause this side effect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The brown deposits on the corneal epithelium are known as Kayser-Fleischer rings, which are commonly seen in patients with Wilson disease. Chlorpromazine is known to cause accumulation of copper and can worsen Wilson disease symptoms. Among the options, chlorpromazine is the most likely antipsychotic drug that the patient has been taking for the past 20 years.
